Z-0075.1
HOUSE BILL 1119
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByRepresentatives Goodman and Simmons; by request of Department of Corrections
Prefiled 12/23/24.Read first time 01/13/25.Referred to Committee on Community Safety.
AN ACT Relating to supervision compliance credit; and amending RCW 9.94A.717.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 9.94A.717 and 2020 c 275 s 2 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) If an offender sentenced under this chapter or chapter 9.94B RCW is supervised by the department, the offender may earn supervision compliance credit in accordance with procedures that are developed and adopted by the department.
(a) The supervision compliance credit shall be awarded to offenders who are in compliance with supervision terms ((and are making progress towards the goals of their individualized supervision case plan, including: Participation in specific targeted interventions, risk-related programming, or treatment; or completing steps towards specific targeted goals that enhance protective factors and stability)), as determined by the department.
(b) For each month in compliance with ((community custody conditions))supervision terms in accordance with (a) of this subsection, an offender may earn supervision compliance credit of ((ten))10 days.
(c) Supervision compliance credit is accrued monthly and time shall not be applied to an offender's term of supervision prior to the earning of the time.
(2) An offender is not eligible to earn supervision compliance credit if he or she:
(a) Was sentenced under RCW 9.94A.507 or 10.95.030;
(b) Was sentenced to any sentencing alternative under ((RCW 9.94A.650, 9.94A.655, 9.94A.660, or 9.94A.670))this chapter;
(c) Is subject to supervision pursuant to RCW 9.94A.745;
(d) Is subject to a governor's conditional commutation;
(e) Has an indeterminate sentence and is subject to parole pursuant to RCW 9.95.017; or
(((e)))(f) Is serving community custody pursuant to early release under RCW 9.94A.730.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The purpose of House Bill 1119 is to modify the regulations concerning the earning of supervision compliance credit for offenders under the supervision of the Washington Department of Corrections. The bill aims to streamline the process for offenders to earn credit for complying with their supervision terms, which can ultimately reduce their time on supervision. Key changes from the previous version include the removal of the requirement for offenders to show progress towards individualized goals and the specification of the amount of credit earned each month, which is now set at 10 days for compliant offenders.

Key Provisions

Supervision Compliance Credit

  • Offenders supervised by the Department of Corrections can earn monthly supervision compliance credit by adhering to their supervision terms.
  • Offenders who maintain compliance will earn 10 days of credit for each month they meet the established supervision terms.
  • Credit is accrued monthly and cannot be applied to supervision terms until it is earned.

Eligibility for Earning Credit

  • Offenders are ineligible for supervision compliance credit if they:
    • Were sentenced under specific serious offenses as outlined in RCW 9.94A.507 or RCW 10.95.030.
    • Were sentenced to any alternative under the provisions of this chapter.
    • Are subject to supervision laws under RCW 9.94A.745.
    • Are subject to a governor's conditional commutation.
    • Have an indeterminate sentence and are on parole as per RCW 9.95.017.
    • Are serving community custody under early release provisions outlined in RCW 9.94A.730.

SUBSTITUTE HOUSE BILL 1119
State of Washington
69th Legislature
2025 Regular Session
ByHouse Appropriations (originally sponsored by Representatives Goodman and Simmons; by request of Department of Corrections)
READ FIRST TIME 02/21/25.
AN ACT Relating to supervision compliance credit; and amending RCW 9.94A.717.
BE IT ENACTED BY THE LEGISLATURE OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON:
Sec. 1. RCW 9.94A.717 and 2020 c 275 s 2 are each amended to read as follows:
(1) If an offender sentenced under this chapter or chapter 9.94B RCW is supervised by the department, the offender may earn supervision compliance credit in accordance with procedures that are developed and adopted by the department. Such procedures shall be available on the department's website.
(a) The supervision compliance credit shall be awarded to offenders who are in compliance with supervision terms ((and are making progress towards the goals of their individualized supervision case plan, including: Participation in specific targeted interventions, risk-related programming, or treatment; or completing steps towards specific targeted goals that enhance protective factors and stability)), as determined by the department.
(b) For each month in compliance with ((community custody conditions))supervision terms in accordance with (a) of this subsection, an offender may earn supervision compliance credit of ((ten))10 days.
(c) Supervision compliance credit is accrued monthly and time shall not be applied to an offender's term of supervision prior to the earning of the time.
(2) An offender is not eligible to earn supervision compliance credit if he or she:
(a) Was sentenced under RCW 9.94A.507 or 10.95.030;
(b) Was sentenced to any sentencing alternative under ((RCW 9.94A.650, 9.94A.655, 9.94A.660, or 9.94A.670))this chapter;
(c) Is subject to supervision pursuant to RCW 9.94A.745;
(d) Is subject to a governor's conditional commutation;
(e) Has an indeterminate sentence and is subject to parole pursuant to RCW 9.95.017; or
(((e)))(f) Is serving community custody pursuant to early release under RCW 9.94A.730.
--- END ---

summary.text:
Purpose

The goal of the edits made to the proposed bill regarding supervision compliance credit is to enhance clarity and accessibility of the credit earning procedures for offenders under supervision. The key change is the addition of a statement requiring that the procedures for earning credits be made available on the department's website. This change emphasizes transparency and makes it easier for offenders to understand their rights and the processes related to compliance credits.

Key Changes

Clarification of Procedures

  • A new sentence has been added to state: "Such procedures shall be available on the department's website." This ensures that offenders can easily access the rules and steps for earning compliance credits.

Removal of Specific Language

  • The language that specified making progress towards individualized supervision case plans has been removed from the eligibility criteria for earning compliance credits, although offenders are still required to be in compliance with supervision terms as determined by the department.

Adjustments in Terminology

  • The term “community custody conditions” has been replaced by the more encompassing term “supervision terms”, which clarifies that the compliance credit applies specifically to the terms of supervision set by the department.

These changes collectively aim to simplify the bill's language while reinforcing the need for accessible guidelines regarding supervision compliance credits.
